comments.body:
Do you have a sense for whether projects will have largely unit tests, or largely driver tests, or some mix of both?

I'm just wondering when (or whether) we should default this to true, and / or remove the flag completely and just generate a test for all apps.

I think it will be a mix for something serious, but for people simply trying out the technology it will be none.

There are two reasons I decided to make this opt-in:
1. To keep simple things simple. One great thing about Dart is that you don't need a project generator to get started. As soon as you have a project generator feature creep tends to get the setup to a point that you can no longer live without a generator. Today, you can `flutter create -o myapp` and literally read through all the generated files in less than 5 minutes and understand what's going on. Good luck doing that with native Android/iOS SDKs.
2. Having tests immediately requires more maintenance. When someone just trying things out, they are likely to break the test as soon as they make the first change in the app and potentially trigger analyzer warnings in Atom.

This option is useful for people whose purpose is to learn how testing works in Flutter, or for those who are committed to building a production app.
Makes sense re: the opt-in choice
Should we have a similar option to create unit tests?  Should we have the ability to create a driver and/or unit test for an existing project?

> Should we have a similar option to create unit tests?

[I think so](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/2102).

> Should we have the ability to create a driver and/or unit test for an existing project?

We could, perhaps, generate basic scaffolding, but not generate a real test, since we don't know what to test in an existing project (we wouldn't even know what to import).

comments.body: Ah, so driver tests live in their own directory (`test_driver`)?

_Now_ they do. This is because we do not have integration with `@TestOn` annotations. If I put driver files in `test`, then `flutter test` will attempt to pick them up. For now, `flutter test` will operate only on `test`, and `flutter drive` will operate only on `test_driver`.
This is awesome - that we can support multiple templates w/ this.
Thanks!  LGTM

You may want to move the additional description to a `final String usageFooter` section; it'll keep the help overview for the general flutter tool terse. We do this for trace and one or two other commands.
The `\n` seems to prevent this text from appearing in the general tool usage list.
That's a bit surprising. Did you delete the bin/cache/flutter_tools.stamp file?

```
$ flutter create --help
Building flutter tool...
Create a new Flutter project.
If run on a project that already exists, this will repair the project, recreating any files that are missing.

Usage: flutter create <output directory>
-h, --help                     Print this usage information.
    --[no-]pub                 Whether to run "pub get" after the project has been created.
                               (defaults to on)

    --[no-]with-driver-test    Also add a flutter_driver dependency and generate a sample 'flutter drive' test.

Run "flutter help" to see global options.
$ flutter --help
Manage your Flutter app development.

Usage: flutter <command> [arguments]

Global options:
-h, --help            Print this usage information.
-v, --verbose         Noisy logging, including all shell commands executed.
-d, --device-id       Target device id.
    --version         Reports the version of this tool.
    --flutter-root    The root directory of the Flutter repository. Uses $FLUTTER_ROOT if set,
                      otherwise defaults to a value derived from the location of this tool.
                      (defaults to "...")

Available commands:
  analyze   Analyze the project's Dart code.
  build     Flutter build commands.
  create    Create a new Flutter project.
  devices   List all connected devices.
  doctor    Show information about the installed tooling.
  drive     Runs Flutter Driver tests for the current project.
  help      Display help information for flutter.
  install   Install a Flutter app on an attached device.
  listen    Listen for changes to files and reload the running app.
  logs      Show log output for running Flutter apps.
  refresh   Build and deploy the Dart code in a Flutter app (Android only).
  run       Run your Flutter app on an attached device.
  stop      Stop your Flutter app on an attached device.
  test      Run Flutter unit tests for the current project (Linux only).
  trace     Start and stop tracing for a running Flutter app (Android only).
  upgrade   Upgrade your copy of Flutter.

Run "flutter help <command>" for more information about a command.
Run "flutter -h -v" for verbose help output, including less commonly used options.

[âœ“] The Android toolchain is fully installed.
[ ] The Atom development environment is not installed.

Run "flutter doctor" for information about installing additional components.
$
```
OK, I was seeing something different locally. It looks like they added (or re-added) this behavior in a recent version: https://github.com/dart-lang/args/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md.
Can you run create while offline with this?
No.  Create still depends on pub.dartlang.org.  We'll need to internalize our Dart package dependencies before it will be possible to run create offline.
Good to know.  Offline can be a non-goal for now, that's fine.
Please file a bug with the linter package to request that this be exposed so that we don't have to cheat.
Done: https://github.com/dart-lang/linter/issues/654
It looks weird to have both `app` and `application` - can you add docs to these so we know what each type means and so that some well-meaning developer doesn't merge them prematurely?
Sure.  There are docs in other places, but you're right, there should be some here.

comments.body:
Slightly more concise way to express this:

```dart
projectDir.absolute.childDirectory(fs.path.join('android', 'app'))
```

(and a few below as well if you feel like changing it)
Thanks, I'll do that. I'm also wrapping that in a function for existence so it only appears once.

`valueHelp: 'sample-id'`

(we should start consistently using `valueHelp` where appropriate, and back-fill existing args when we touch them.)
Ahh, I thought that was only printed when there were "allowed" values. Done.
Aren't the IDs allowed to contain dots?
(I'm just looking at the PR description ðŸ˜„ )
Yes, but you're not looking at the regex... :-) . It's disallowing ("^") anything that isn't a dash, a "word character" or a dot.  So, yes, dots are allowed, as are dashes.
It doesn't look like `overwrite` is defined.
Whoops: a half-completed thought there... I implemented --overwrite.
Document what this does, including what the return value means.
Done.

the PR description says it's enabled by default, but it's disabled by default here.

Once we're confident it works for all users, we'll definitely want to make this default to true.  The reason we'd start with it off is just to let users opt-in to it before we open the flood-gates.
I've updated the PR description.
Shall we use https://api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/SingleChildScrollView-class.html instead of https://master-api.flutter.dev/flutter/widgets/SingleChildScrollView-class.html ?
That doesn't have the sample code section yet
I see. LGTM. Maybe create some issue that reminds us to change back to "api.flutter.dev" once the sample code is there.

comments.body: Add a comment line for when this would happen?
Done
I assume runCommand will always crash first? We wouldn't want the usageValues getter to crash.
That is correct. The tool will exit at that point, so we won't get stats for this particular case.
This is a _little_ scary - who will update this as new keywords get added?

I'm not actually sure if pub can add more restrictions here. Grammatically, there are no issues since package-scheme imports are just URIs, and `package:abstract/abstract.dart` is in no way ambiguous. 

But the analyzer function we were using before wasn't the pub source of truth either, and in the worst case `pub get` fails with an error message that they must change the package name (only in a single place).
Also, the pub restrictions only matter if you publish to pub - which for applications is somewhat pointless
Does this still need to be negatable to support `--no-androidx` usage?

comments.body: this is confusing, why do we need to only check projects if we're creating an example app

As a side effect, this method always generates the `GeneratedPluginRegstraint` files for iOS and Android unless the checkProject flag is true. When the plugin is not for mobile, this method still generate those files, including iOS and Android.
(ew.)
makes sense
Do you guys think `pluginExampleApp` is confusing? I am thinking it might be better just to call it `checkProjects` or `checkProjectsWhileEnsuringTooling`
I think the non specificity of "checkProjects" is what's throwing me off (I know you didn't name it).  Like, check what?  If that was a better name, `pluginExampleApp` might make sense.

By looking at the code of `ensureReadyForPlatformSpecificTooling`, I also not sure what that meant. @jonahwilliams  do you have any idea? Maybe we can add a TODO comment on that method to either fix the param name or add some doc/comments on the `checkProjects` param?
yeah, TODO for now.
done
I didn't see an issue tracking this crash, surprisingly (it's not the same as https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/43734)
Are you OK if we just fix it in this PR? Or do you think a separate PR would be better?
I'm fine with fixing here, I'm just surprised I couldn't find a crash report of this.

They may not have a `platform` key if they generated in an older plugin format, right?
```
Add below lines to under the `platform:` key in the `plugins:` section of your `pubspec.yaml`
```
? Something like that?  I guess it doesn't matter so much because we gave them a link to more detailed instructions below.
I think it makes sense to also give users a warning if they are using the old format, I updated the message for those users. PTAL.
The cast<String>() will throw if the pubspec is not formatted correctly, does createPlatformsYamlMap validate the structure?
Yes, `createPlatformsYamlMap` creates a valid <String, dynamic> YamlMap based on a Map<String, dynamic>
if that string is not a valid path, `Uri.file()` will throw. I'm thinking we should catch that, especially since we're re-constructing the absolute path.
oh wait, nvm. i see the manifest is checked in.
